ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: an overview of the history of affect theory's development across a few disciplines; its application in ethnic studies and critical race theory; its application to global processes of political economy

This class introduced me to a lot of really useful and thought-provoking material on the intersection of race and affect, which I feel like is an oft looked-over intersection within the field of affect theory. The way in which the course was framed around personhood and people felt also very useful for thinking about how to conduct and interpret ethnographic work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: the small class size was a big strength for in depth conversation, but some weeks had too many readings to get to in conversation-consider paring down

The strength of this course is also its weakness: I appreciated being exposed to so much material, but sometimes felt overwhelmed by the shear density and quantity of reading for the week. Also, submitting and reading response before class also weighed in on these anxieties.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! I learned so much and found most of it useful to my work.
Yes, definitely! I learned so much this semester from this course alone!
